li.p: We can describe a relationship between variables with a table of values, a graph, or an equation.
Linear models have equations of the following form: y = (\text{starting value}) + (\text{rate of change})\cdot x
To make a useful graph, we must choose appropriate scales for the axes.

assemblage.title: General Form for a Linear Equation
assemblage.p: The graph of any equation Ax+By=C where A and B are not both equal to zero, is a straight line.

li.p: The intercepts of a graph are the points where the graph crosses the axes.
We can use the intercepts to graph a line.

assemblage.title: To Graph a Line Using the Intercept Method:

li.p: Find the intercepts of the line.
To find the x-intercept, set y=0 and solve for x.
To find the y-intercept, set x = 0 and solve for y.
Choose a value for x and find a third point on the line.
Draw a line through the points.
The intercepts are also useful for interpreting a model.

Delbert says that the intercepts of the line 3x + 5y = 30 are (10, 6). What is wrong with his answer?
